page.title: 16MARSHLAND
page.content: Tilbury and East Tilbury are built on the marshland flats which form part of the floodplain of the {River {Thames.}This accounts for the lack of building there before this century. People survived in isolated farms with "marsh fever" taking its toll of life. At Chadwell Hill and Gun Hill the land rises to ten metres above sea level and remains at that in the far north of our survey.This makes a flat,level landscape dotted by gravel pits and housing. Because of drainage and modern farming methods the lower land is now devoted to arable farming _ mostly wheat,barley and rape. Sheep are on the hill and the higher flat lands are farmed again for crops. There are many marshland creatures,especially in the ditches. Many horses are also kept here.
